_description: Comprehensive diet profile definitions with detailed guidelines
_source: Based on Diet Compass research, nutritional science, and established dietary approaches

profiles.name: Mediterranean
profiles.summary: Heart-healthy eating pattern rich in olive oil, fish, vegetables, and whole grains.
profiles.description: The Mediterranean diet is one of the most studied and recommended eating patterns for longevity and heart health. It emphasizes whole foods, healthy fats, and a plant-forward approach while including moderate amounts of fish, dairy, and wine.
principles: Abundant vegetables and fruits daily
Olive oil as primary fat source
Fish and seafood 2-3 times per week
Moderate dairy (especially yogurt and cheese)
Whole grains over refined grains
Nuts and legumes consumed daily
Limit red meat to occasional consumption
Wine in moderation with meals (optional)

mealStructure.breakfast: Greek yogurt with nuts and fruit, or whole grain bread with olive oil and tomatoes
mealStructure.lunch: Large meal - fish or legumes with vegetables and whole grains
mealStructure.dinner: Lighter meal - salad with protein, vegetables, olive oil
mealStructure.snacks: Nuts, fresh fruit, vegetables with hummus

profiles.specialConsiderations: One of the most studied and recommended diets for longevity and heart health. Linked to reduced risk of cardiovascular disease, diabetes, and cognitive decline. Very sustainable long-term.
profiles.scientificBasis: Extensive research from Mediterranean populations showing reduced mortality and chronic disease rates. Rich in polyphenols, omega-3 fatty acids, and fiber.

profiles.name: Longevity Protocol (Diet Compass)
profiles.summary: Science-based diet optimized for lifespan extension based on Diet Compass research by Bas Kast.
profiles.description: This protocol implements four key scientific mechanisms: Protein-Leverage Effect, mTOR Modulation, Anti-Inflammatory Balance, and Gut Microbiome Support. Built on extensive longevity research compiled in 'The Diet Compass'.
principles: Eat real food your great-grandmother would recognize
Plants as main course - vegetables are the meal, protein is the complement
Protein moderation: ~15% of calories (60-75g daily), prioritize plant and fish sources
Quality fats: Olive oil, nuts, seeds, oily fish (omega-3 focus)
Slow carbohydrates only: Legumes, whole grains, vegetables (avoid fast carbs)
Fermentation priority: Yoghurt > milk; include sauerkraut, kimchi, kefir
Time-restricted eating: 10-14 hour eating window (e.g., 8 AM - 6 PM)
mTOR inhibitors daily: Coffee, olive oil, green tea, turmeric
Weekly 24-hour fast for autophagy activation (optional but recommended)
Post-meal movement: 10-minute walks after lunch and dinner
No snacking between meals to maintain insulin sensitivity
Fish 3-4x/week, red meat rarely (few times yearly)

mealStructure.breakfast: Nutrient-dense start - Greek yogurt with berries and nuts, or protein-rich bar with omega-3
mealStructure.lunch: Largest meal - Legume-based (hummus bowl, lentil soup, chickpea salad) with whole grains and fermented dairy. Always followed by 10-minute walk.
mealStructure.dinner: Lighter, early (5-6 PM) - Fish or plant protein with abundant vegetables, NO carbs. Followed by walk.
mealStructure.snacks: NONE - no eating between meals to maintain insulin sensitivity

weeklyFast.description: 24-hour fast from Thursday lunch (12 PM) to Friday lunch (1 PM)
weeklyFast.allowed: Water, black coffee, herbal tea, green tea only
weeklyFast.notAllowed: Any food, milk, cream, sweeteners, bone broth
weeklyFast.breakFastMeal: Light - protein bar and salad with hummus
weeklyFast.benefits: Activates autophagy, enhances mTOR inhibition, improves metabolic flexibility

scientificMechanisms.proteinLeverage: Eat until protein needs met (~15%). High-quality protein = earlier satiety = fewer calories.
scientificMechanisms.mTORModulation: Plant proteins and certain foods (coffee, olive oil, green tea, turmeric) inhibit mTOR, slowing aging.
scientificMechanisms.antiInflammatory: Omega-3s, fermented foods, plant compounds reduce chronic inflammation.
scientificMechanisms.gutMicrobiome: Fermented foods and fiber feed beneficial bacteria, improving metabolism and immunity.

dietCompassScore.notes: Exceptional omega-3 (5.5-7g), high fiber (35-45g), plant-forward, mTOR inhibitors daily

profiles.specialConsiderations: Based on 'The Diet Compass' by Bas Kast. Emphasizes protective foods, mTOR inhibition, and autophagy activation. Includes optional weekly 24-hour fast. Adjust carbs based on personal metabolic response. Not a quick fix - designed as sustainable lifestyle.

profiles.name: La Dieta
profiles.summary: Temporary cleansing protocol for preparation before plant medicine retreats.
profiles.description: La Dieta is a progressive cleansing diet designed to prepare the body, mind, and spirit for deep healing work. It operates on a reverse timeline from a specific retreat date, with restrictions increasing as the retreat approaches. This is NOT a long-term diet but a temporary preparation protocol.
principles: The lighter the food, the easier access to deep healing
Start as early as possible (minimum 7 days before retreat)
Progressive restriction increases closer to retreat date
Focus on clean, fresh, unprocessed foods
Physical cleansing removes stimulants and toxins
Energetic preparation for spiritual connection
Eliminate foods that could create adverse interactions
Digestive rest through progressive lightening

phase1.name: Base Cleansing Phase
phase1.timing: At least 7 days before retreat (can start weeks or months earlier)
phase1.description: Initial cleansing phase - remove stimulants, processed foods, and heavy proteins
foodsToInclude: Grains: basmati rice, black rice, red rice, quinoa, couscous, millet, buckwheat
Proteins: free-range chicken, fresh fish, sardines, eggs
Fats: olive oil, seeds (sunflower, chia), macca powder
Limited dairy: good quality probiotic yoghurt (small amounts)
Beverages: lemon water (drink lots), herbal teas, dandelion coffee, almond milk (unsweetened), coconut water

phase2.name: Enhanced Restriction Phase
phase2.description: All Phase 1 restrictions continue, PLUS additional eliminations for deeper cleansing
additionalRestrictions: ALL fermented products (soy, sauerkraut, vinegars, pickles, kombucha, miso)
Coconut and coconut products (including coconut water)
phase2.emphasis: Continue fresh vegetables, fresh fruit, clean proteins, simple grains - but lighter, simpler preparations

phase3.name: Minimal Food Phase
phase3.description: Strict timing and minimal food intake for optimal preparation

mealTiming.lunch: Light lunch ~1 PM from allowed foods
mealTiming.evening: After 2 PM: ONLY water, lemon juice, light herbal teas

additionalRestrictions.medications: Must stop 4 weeks prior: antidepressants, sleep meds, barbiturates, beta-blockers, steroids, antibiotics (1 week min). Only Advil permitted.
additionalRestrictions.substances: Avoid 4 weeks before and after: psychedelics, street drugs. Marijuana 1 week minimum.
additionalRestrictions.lifestyle: 3 days before and after: sexual abstinence, avoid violent/disturbing media

vanessaGuidelines.calculatePhase: Determine current phase based on days until retreat
vanessaGuidelines.mealPlanning: Phase 1: varied and substantial. Phase 2: lighter, simpler. Phase 3: strict timing.
vanessaGuidelines.hydration: Emphasize lemon water and herbal teas, increase closer to retreat
vanessaGuidelines.progressiveSimplification: Meals should get lighter and simpler as retreat approaches
vanessaGuidelines.timing: Phase 3 timing is CRITICAL - no solid food after 2 PM on retreat day

profiles.specialConsiderations: TEMPORARY cleansing diet for retreat preparation. NOT for long-term use. Requires retreat date for proper timeline calculation. The earlier you start (beyond minimum 7 days), the more thorough the cleansing. Consult retreat organizers with questions.

profiles.name: Keto / Low-Carb
profiles.summary: Very low carbohydrate, high fat diet that induces ketosis for metabolic benefits.
profiles.description: The ketogenic diet drastically reduces carbohydrate intake to induce a metabolic state called ketosis, where the body burns fat for fuel instead of glucose. This can lead to rapid weight loss, improved mental clarity, and better blood sugar control.
principles: Minimize carbohydrates (<20-50g/day for ketosis)
High healthy fats (70-80% of calories)
Moderate protein (20-25% - too much kicks you out of ketosis)
Focus on whole, unprocessed foods
Avoid all grains, sugars, and starchy vegetables
Track net carbs (total carbs minus fiber)
Stay hydrated and supplement electrolytes
Monitor ketone levels to confirm ketosis
foodsToAvoid: most fruits (except small portions of berries)

mealStructure.breakfast: Eggs with avocado and bacon, or bulletproof coffee with MCT oil
mealStructure.lunch: Salad with fatty protein (salmon, chicken thighs) and olive oil dressing
mealStructure.dinner: Meat or fish with non-starchy vegetables cooked in butter/oil

dailyTargets.protein: 0.8-1g per pound of lean body mass

profiles.specialConsiderations: Requires careful monitoring and adaptation period (keto flu). Not suitable for everyone. May conflict with plant-based diets. Consult healthcare provider before starting, especially if you have diabetes or kidney issues. Track ketones to confirm ketosis.

profiles.name: Vegetarian
profiles.summary: Plant-based diet that excludes meat and fish but includes dairy and eggs.
profiles.description: A vegetarian diet emphasizes plant foods while allowing eggs and dairy products. It provides health benefits of plant-based eating while offering flexibility with protein sources and nutrients like B12 and calcium.
principles: No meat, poultry, or fish
Abundant vegetables and fruits daily
Legumes and beans as primary protein sources
Whole grains preferred over refined grains
Dairy and eggs allowed and encouraged for nutrients
Variety of plant proteins to ensure complete amino acids
Include iron-rich plants with vitamin C for absorption
Consider B12 supplementation or fortified foods

mealStructure.breakfast: Oatmeal with nuts and fruit, eggs with vegetables, or yogurt parfait
mealStructure.lunch: Legume-based meals (bean burrito, lentil soup, chickpea curry) with grains
mealStructure.dinner: Tofu/tempeh stir-fry, pasta with vegetables, or grain bowls
mealStructure.snacks: Hummus with vegetables, cheese, nuts, fruit

nutrientConsiderations.b12: Supplement or eat fortified foods daily (critical)
nutrientConsiderations.iron: Combine plant sources (beans, spinach) with vitamin C (tomatoes, citrus)
nutrientConsiderations.omega3: Include walnuts, flax seeds, chia seeds, or algae supplement
nutrientConsiderations.protein: Combine different plant proteins (beans + rice, hummus + pita)
nutrientConsiderations.calcium: Dairy, fortified plant milks, leafy greens

profiles.specialConsiderations: Ensure adequate B12, iron, and omega-3 from supplements or fortified foods. Combine plant proteins for complete amino acids. Very compatible with other healthy eating patterns.

profiles.name: High Protein
profiles.summary: Emphasizes protein-rich foods for muscle building, satiety, and weight management.
profiles.description: A high-protein diet increases protein intake to 25-35% of calories to support muscle growth, enhance satiety, and promote weight loss. It's particularly effective for active individuals and those looking to preserve muscle while losing fat.
principles: High protein intake (25-35% of calories)
Lean meats, fish, eggs, and dairy emphasized
Plant proteins included (legumes, tofu, tempeh)
Moderate carbs and fats for balance
Focus on whole, minimally processed foods
Distribute protein across all meals (20-40g per meal)
Combine with strength training for best results
Ensure adequate hydration (protein metabolism needs water)
foodsToAvoid: excessive fats (if combined with high protein)

mealStructure.breakfast: Eggs with vegetables, Greek yogurt with protein granola, or protein smoothie
mealStructure.lunch: Grilled chicken/fish with quinoa and vegetables, or large protein-rich salad
mealStructure.dinner: Lean protein (150-200g) with vegetables and small portion of complex carbs
mealStructure.snacks: Protein shake, cottage cheese, hard-boiled eggs, protein bars

dailyTargets.protein: 1.6-2.2g per kg body weight (or 0.7-1g per pound)
dailyTargets.timing: Protein within 2 hours post-workout for muscle synthesis

profiles.specialConsiderations: Ensure adequate hydration (3-4L water daily). Monitor kidney health with very high protein intake. Best combined with strength training. May need to adjust based on activity level. Not recommended for those with kidney disease.

profiles.name: Flexitarian
profiles.summary: Primarily plant-based with occasional meat and fish for flexibility.
profiles.description: The flexitarian diet offers the health benefits of vegetarianism while maintaining the flexibility to include meat and fish occasionally. It's ideal for those transitioning to plant-based eating or wanting a balanced, sustainable approach.
principles: Plants as foundation of every meal
Meat and fish occasionally (1-3 times per week)
Focus on whole, minimally processed foods
Quality over quantity when choosing animal products
Sustainable and ethical food choices
Flexible approach - no strict rules
Emphasize variety and seasonal produce
Listen to your body's needs
foodsToAvoid: excessive red meat (limit to rare occasions)

mealStructure.breakfast: Oatmeal with nuts and berries, or eggs with vegetables (2-3x/week)
mealStructure.lunch: Legume-based meals (lentil curry, chickpea salad) or occasional fish
mealStructure.dinner: Plant-forward meals with occasional animal protein as side
mealStructure.snacks: Nuts, fruits, vegetables with hummus, yogurt

meatGuidelines.preparation: Grilled, baked, or steamed - not fried

profiles.specialConsiderations: Very compatible with most other diets. Great for gradual transitions to plant-based eating. Flexible enough for social situations. Environmentally sustainable. Lower cost than heavy meat-based diets.

profiles.name: Intermittent Fasting
profiles.summary: Time-restricted eating pattern that cycles between fasting and eating periods.
profiles.description: Intermittent fasting focuses on WHEN you eat rather than WHAT you eat. The most common approach is 16:8 (16 hours fasting, 8 hour eating window), which aligns with circadian rhythms and promotes metabolic health.
principles: Eat within consistent 8-hour window (e.g., 12 PM - 8 PM or 10 AM - 6 PM)
Fast for 16 hours (including sleep time)
Focus on nutrient-dense foods during eating window
Hydration during fasting (water, black coffee, tea)
Quality over quantity - make every meal count
No snacking outside eating window
Align eating window with your lifestyle and circadian rhythm
Break fast with balanced meal, not junk food
foodsToAvoid: excessive calories (fasting doesn't mean binge eating)

16_8.name: 16:8 (Most Popular)
16_8.example: Fast: 8 PM - 12 PM. Eat: 12 PM - 8 PM
16_8.difficulty: Moderate - skip breakfast or late dinner

14_10.name: 14:10 (Beginner Friendly)
14_10.example: Fast: 8 PM - 10 AM. Eat: 10 AM - 8 PM

18_6.name: 18:6 (Advanced)
18_6.example: Fast: 6 PM - 12 PM. Eat: 12 PM - 6 PM

benefits.metabolic: Improved insulin sensitivity, enhanced fat burning, cellular autophagy
benefits.cognitive: Increased mental clarity, focus, and brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF)
benefits.longevity: Activates anti-aging pathways, reduces inflammation, promotes cellular repair
benefits.weightLoss: Natural calorie restriction, preserved muscle mass, targeted fat loss

profiles.specialConsiderations: Timing matters more than specific foods. Compatible with other dietary approaches (can do keto IF, vegan IF, etc.). Not recommended for pregnant/nursing women, children, or those with eating disorders. May take 1-2 weeks to adapt.
compatibleWith: any - can combine with other diet approaches

profiles.name: Vegan
profiles.summary: Entirely plant-based diet excluding all animal products.
profiles.description: A vegan diet eliminates all animal products including meat, fish, dairy, eggs, and honey. When well-planned, it can provide all necessary nutrients while offering ethical, environmental, and health benefits.
principles: No animal products of any kind
Abundant vegetables and fruits daily
Legumes and beans for protein
Whole grains for energy and nutrients
Nuts and seeds for healthy fats and protein
Fortified foods for B12, D, and calcium
Variety is key for complete nutrition
Plan meals to ensure adequate protein and nutrients

mealStructure.breakfast: Oatmeal with plant milk, nuts, and fruit, or tofu scramble with vegetables
mealStructure.lunch: Buddha bowls with grains, legumes, vegetables, tahini dressing
mealStructure.dinner: Stir-fries, curries, pasta dishes, or grain bowls with plant protein
mealStructure.snacks: Hummus with vegetables, fruit with nut butter, energy balls

proteinSources.legumes: Lentils (18g per cup), chickpeas (15g), black beans (15g)
proteinSources.soy: Tofu (20g per cup), tempeh (31g per cup), edamame (17g per cup)
proteinSources.grains: Quinoa (8g per cup), oats (6g per cup)
proteinSources.nuts: Almonds (6g per oz), peanuts (7g per oz)
proteinSources.seeds: Hemp seeds (10g per oz), pumpkin seeds (9g per oz)
proteinSources.target: Aim for 0.8-1g protein per kg body weight from varied sources

criticalNutrients.b12: MUST supplement or eat fortified foods daily (2.4 mcg/day)
criticalNutrients.vitaminD: Supplement recommended (1000-2000 IU), or fortified foods
criticalNutrients.omega3: Algae supplement (EPA/DHA) or emphasize flax, chia, walnuts (ALA)
criticalNutrients.iron: Combine plant sources with vitamin C, consider supplement if deficient
criticalNutrients.calcium: Fortified plant milks, tofu, leafy greens, or supplement

profiles.specialConsiderations: Supplement B12 is ESSENTIAL (not optional). Ensure adequate protein variety and quantity. Combine iron-rich foods with vitamin C. Consider omega-3 (EPA/DHA) from algae. Well-planned vegan diet is healthy for all life stages per Academy of Nutrition and Dietetics.

profiles.name: MIND Diet
profiles.summary: Brain-health focused diet combining Mediterranean and DASH approaches for cognitive function.
profiles.description: The MIND diet (Mediterranean-DASH Intervention for Neurodegenerative Delay) specifically targets brain health and dementia prevention. Research shows it can reduce Alzheimer's risk by up to 53% when followed closely.
principles: Berries (especially blueberries) at least 2 servings/week
Leafy greens daily (6+ servings/week)
Nuts regularly (5+ servings/week)
Olive oil as primary fat
Whole grains daily (3+ servings)
Fish at least once per week
Beans and legumes frequently (3+ servings/week)
Poultry at least twice per week
Limit butter (<1 tablespoon/day)
Limit cheese (<1 serving/week)
Limit red meat (<4 servings/week)
Avoid fried foods, pastries, and sweets

macroGuidance.fat: moderate (30-35%, emphasize olive oil and omega-3)

mealStructure.breakfast: Oatmeal with berries and walnuts, or whole grain toast with avocado
mealStructure.lunch: Large salad with leafy greens, beans, vegetables, olive oil dressing
mealStructure.dinner: Fish or poultry with vegetables and whole grain side

brainHealthFoods.tier2: Olive oil, fish, beans, whole grains
brainHealthFoods.antioxidants: Berries provide anthocyanins for brain protection
brainHealthFoods.omega3: Fish and walnuts for DHA (brain structure)

profiles.specialConsiderations: Specifically designed for brain health and dementia prevention. Research shows 53% reduced Alzheimer's risk with adherence. Emphasizes foods with neuroprotective compounds. Compatible with most dietary preferences.
profiles.scientificBasis: Rush University research on aging and cognition. Combines Mediterranean diet and DASH diet principles targeting brain health specifically.

profiles.name: Kid-Friendly
profiles.summary: Nutritious, familiar foods that children typically enjoy and parents approve.
profiles.description: A kid-friendly diet focuses on providing complete nutrition through foods with familiar flavors and textures that children find appealing. It emphasizes whole foods while accommodating children's preferences and developmental needs.
principles: Familiar flavors and textures children recognize
Balanced nutrition for growth and development
Age-appropriate portions and preparations
Hide or blend vegetables when needed
Fun, colorful presentation
Limited spice and complex flavors
Involve kids in meal selection when possible
Establish healthy eating patterns early

mealStructure.breakfast: Cereal with milk, pancakes, eggs, or yogurt with fruit
mealStructure.lunch: Sandwiches, pasta with mild sauce, chicken nuggets with vegetables
mealStructure.dinner: Mild proteins (chicken, fish) with familiar sides (rice, pasta, potatoes)
mealStructure.snacks: Fruit, cheese, crackers, yogurt, vegetables with dip

ageGuidelines.toddlers: Small portions, soft textures, finger foods, variety for exposure
ageGuidelines.preschool: Involve in prep, colorful plates, consistent routine
ageGuidelines.schoolAge: Balanced meals, pack nutritious lunches, limit processed snacks
ageGuidelines.teens: Increased portions, protein for growth, healthy convenience options

strategies: Bake into muffins or pancakes (zucchini, carrot)

profiles.specialConsiderations: Broadly compatible with family meals. Focus on nutrients and palatability over strict dietary rules. Avoid forcing foods - offer variety and let children explore. Model healthy eating. Keep it positive and pressure-free.
compatibleWith: most diets - adapts to family needs

profiles.name: Pescatarian
profiles.summary: Plant-based diet that includes fish and seafood but excludes other meats.
profiles.description: Pescatarian eating combines the health benefits of a vegetarian diet with the nutritional advantages of fish and seafood, particularly omega-3 fatty acids. It's associated with longevity and heart health benefits.
principles: No meat or poultry - fish and seafood only
Emphasize fatty fish for omega-3 (2-3 times per week)
Plant foods as foundation
Include variety of seafood (fish, shellfish, mollusks)
Eggs and dairy allowed
Whole grains and legumes for plant protein
Choose sustainable, wild-caught fish when possible
Vary fish types to minimize mercury exposure

mealStructure.breakfast: Eggs with vegetables, Greek yogurt with fruit, or oatmeal
mealStructure.lunch: Tuna salad, sardine toast, or legume-based meals
mealStructure.dinner: Grilled/baked fish with vegetables and grains
mealStructure.snacks: Nuts, fruit, vegetables with hummus, cheese

fishGuidelines.frequency: 2-4 times per week for optimal omega-3
fishGuidelines.bestChoices: Salmon, sardines, mackerel, herring, anchovies (high omega-3, low mercury)
fishGuidelines.goodChoices: Cod, haddock, tilapia, trout, mussels, clams
fishGuidelines.sustainability: Look for MSC certified or local sustainable sources

nutrientAdvantages.omega3: Excellent EPA/DHA from fish (no conversion needed like plant omega-3)

profiles.specialConsiderations: Offers omega-3 advantages over vegetarian diet. Pescatarian pattern associated with highest longevity in research. Vary fish types to minimize mercury. Choose sustainable sources. Generally easier to follow than vegan (no B12 supplementation needed).

profiles.name: Paleo
profiles.summary: Eating pattern based on foods available to our Paleolithic ancestors.
profiles.description: The Paleo diet focuses on whole, unprocessed foods similar to what hunter-gatherers ate: meats, fish, vegetables, fruits, nuts, and seeds. It excludes grains, legumes, dairy, and processed foods.
principles: Eat whole, unprocessed foods only
No grains, legumes, or dairy
Emphasize quality meats (grass-fed, wild)
Abundant vegetables and some fruits
Healthy fats from natural sources
No refined sugars or processed foods
Focus on food quality and sourcing
Movement and lifestyle matter too
foodsToEmphasize: healthy fats (avocado, coconut oil, olive oil)

mealStructure.breakfast: Eggs with vegetables and avocado, or sweet potato hash with meat
mealStructure.lunch: Salad with grilled chicken or fish, vegetables, and nuts
mealStructure.dinner: Meat or fish with roasted vegetables

profiles.specialConsiderations: Controversial elimination of legumes and grains (nutrient-dense foods). May be expensive (quality meats). Can be high in saturated fat if not careful. Athletic individuals may need more carbs. Not suitable for vegetarians/vegans.

profiles.name: DASH Diet
profiles.summary: Dietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension - designed to lower blood pressure.
profiles.description: The DASH diet was developed to prevent and treat high blood pressure through dietary changes. It emphasizes fruits, vegetables, whole grains, and low-fat dairy while limiting sodium, saturated fat, and added sugars.
principles: Reduce sodium to <2,300mg/day (ideally <1,500mg)
Emphasize potassium-rich foods
Include calcium and magnesium sources
Lots of fruits and vegetables (8-10 servings/day)
Whole grains over refined
Lean proteins preferred
Low-fat or fat-free dairy
Limit saturated fats and added sugars
foodsToAvoid: high-sodium foods (processed meats, canned soups, chips)
profiles.specialConsiderations: Clinically proven to lower blood pressure in 2 weeks. Also reduces cholesterol and supports weight loss. Endorsed by American Heart Association. High potassium intake (from fruits/vegetables) is key. Read labels for sodium.
profiles.scientificBasis: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute research. Gold standard for hypertension management through diet.

profiles.name: Anti-Inflammatory
profiles.summary: Diet designed to reduce chronic inflammation through food choices.
profiles.description: Chronic inflammation is linked to many diseases including heart disease, cancer, and autoimmune conditions. This diet emphasizes anti-inflammatory foods while eliminating inflammatory triggers.
principles: Emphasize omega-3 fatty acids
Include antioxidant-rich foods daily
Eliminate inflammatory triggers
Focus on colorful fruits and vegetables
Choose whole grains over refined
Include herbs and spices (turmeric, ginger)
Limit omega-6 fatty acids
Avoid processed and fried foods

antiInflammatoryFoods.topTier: Turmeric (with black pepper), fatty fish, berries, leafy greens
antiInflammatoryFoods.oils: Extra virgin olive oil, flaxseed oil

omega3VsOmega6.target: Ratio of 1:4 or better (omega-3 to omega-6)

profiles.specialConsiderations: Particularly beneficial for autoimmune conditions, arthritis, inflammatory bowel disease. Turmeric + black pepper combination increases absorption 2000%. Focus on colorful variety. May see benefits in 2-4 weeks.

profiles.name: Low FODMAP
profiles.summary: Therapeutic diet for managing IBS and digestive sensitivities.
profiles.description: Low FODMAP diet restricts fermentable carbohydrates that can trigger digestive symptoms in sensitive individuals. It's a temporary elimination diet (4-6 weeks) followed by systematic reintroduction to identify triggers.
principles: Eliminate high-FODMAP foods for 4-6 weeks
Systematically reintroduce foods one at a time
Identify personal trigger foods
NOT a long-term diet - reintroduce as many foods as tolerated
Work with dietitian for proper implementation
Keep food and symptom diary
Ensure adequate nutrition despite restrictions
foodsToEmphasize: low-FODMAP vegetables (carrots, cucumber, spinach, zucchini, bell peppers)
foodsToAvoid: high-FODMAP fruits (apples, pears, watermelon, dried fruits)
lactose-containing dairy (milk, soft cheeses, ice cream)

phases.personalization: Long-term modified diet with known triggers avoided

profiles.specialConsiderations: MUST be temporary - not nutritionally complete long-term. Work with registered dietitian familiar with FODMAP protocol. Keep detailed food diary. Reintroduce foods systematically. Goal is to identify triggers, not avoid forever. IBS-D, IBS-C, and IBS-M may respond differently.
compatibleWith: can be adapted to most diets with guidance

profiles.name: Whole30
profiles.summary: 30-day elimination diet focusing on whole, unprocessed foods to reset eating habits.
profiles.description: Whole30 is a strict 30-day elimination program designed to reset your relationship with food, identify sensitivities, and establish healthy eating patterns. After 30 days, foods are systematically reintroduced.
principles: 30 days of strict adherence (no cheating - restart if you slip)
Eat whole, unprocessed foods only
No sugar, alcohol, grains, legumes, or dairy for 30 days
No recreating baked goods with approved ingredients
No stepping on scale during the 30 days
Focus on non-scale victories (energy, sleep, mood)
Systematic reintroduction after 30 days to identify sensitivities
foodsToEmphasize: healthy fats (avocado, olive oil, coconut oil, ghee)
foodsToAvoid: added sugar or sweeteners (including honey, maple syrup, stevia)
alcohol (in any form, even for cooking)
dairy (milk, cheese, yogurt, butter - ghee is OK)
baked goods or treats (even with compliant ingredients)

thirtyDayRules.commitment: Full 30 days, no exceptions - one slip means restart
thirtyDayRules.noRecreations: Don't make Paleo pancakes, bread, etc.
thirtyDayRules.noScale: Don't weigh yourself during the 30 days
thirtyDayRules.focusOn: How you feel, energy levels, sleep quality, mental clarity
thirtyDayRules.afterThirty: Systematic reintroduction of food groups one at a time

reintroductionProtocol.day31: Reintroduce legumes for one day, then back to Whole30 for 2 days
reintroductionProtocol.day34: Reintroduce non-gluten grains, then back to Whole30 for 2 days
reintroductionProtocol.day37: Reintroduce dairy, then back to Whole30 for 2 days
reintroductionProtocol.observe: Track symptoms, energy, digestion, sleep for each reintroduction

profiles.specialConsiderations: Designed as a 30-day reset, not long-term diet. Very strict - requires meal planning and label reading. Social situations can be challenging. Eliminates nutrient-dense foods (legumes, whole grains) temporarily. Not sustainable long-term but useful for identifying sensitivities.

profiles.name: Gut Health Protocol
profiles.summary: Diet optimized for digestive health and microbiome diversity.
profiles.description: This protocol focuses on feeding beneficial gut bacteria, reducing inflammation in the digestive tract, and promoting a diverse, healthy microbiome through specific food choices.
principles: Emphasize prebiotic foods (feed good bacteria)
Include probiotic foods daily (provide good bacteria)
Maximize fiber diversity (30+ plant foods per week)
Limit inflammatory foods
Support gut lining integrity
Manage stress (gut-brain axis)
Stay hydrated
Consider food sensitivities
foodsToEmphasize: fermented foods (yogurt, kefir, sauerkraut, kimchi, miso, tempeh)
prebiotic foods (garlic, onions, leeks, asparagus, bananas, oats)
high-fiber foods (vegetables, fruits, whole grains, legumes)
diverse plant foods (aim for 30+ different plants per week)
polyphenol-rich foods (berries, dark chocolate, green tea)
foodsToAvoid: potential trigger foods (gluten, dairy if sensitive)

microbiomeDiversity.strategy: Rotate vegetables, fruits, grains, legumes, nuts, seeds, herbs
microbiomeDiversity.benefit: More diverse microbiome = better health outcomes

profiles.specialConsiderations: Work with healthcare provider if you have diagnosed gut conditions (IBD, SIBO, etc.). May need to modify for FODMAP sensitivity. Gradually increase fiber to avoid bloating. Stress management is crucial (gut-brain axis). Sleep and exercise also impact gut health.
